page.title: 14Sands and peats
page.content:
As further north in the bay, the sands of beach and lower dunes conceal a buried peat layer. Normally this is not visible but is quite often exposed not so may yards from the sea wall at less than a metre depth. In places the remains of tree stumps such as alder can be seen. This peat has recently been dated by use of Carbon 14 to some 2000 years B.C. On occasion sherds of prehistoric pottery, mainly of Neolithic age, have been found. These peats, referred to as "buried forests", capture the public imagination though the range of ideas about them is quite startling.
The rocks are sedimentary rocks of great age and supply the black pebbles found along the base of the sea wall.
